Award.AwardTitle: Approaches to the Aftermath of Intergroup Violence: Effects of Impunity, Trials, and Truth Commissions on Intergroup Peace and Reconciliation Between Victims and Perpetrators

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
What is the best way to achieve reconciliation and peace following international or inter-ethnic conflict and violence? Impunity, trials or tribunals, and truth commissions are different methods to that have been used to try to resolve conflicts. Dr. Bernhard Leidner (University of Massachusetts Amherst) and colleagues will test which approaches to international/inter-ethnic violence (AIVs) are most likely to facilitate reconciliation and peace in post-conflict societies. They have developed a model explaining the consequences and underlying mechanisms of different AIVs among perpetrators and victims. Dr. Leidner and his collaborators hypothesize that perceived fairness of an AIV leads to increased willingness to reconcile and decreased motivation for future violence; and this occurs by increasing empathy for, and decreasing anger at and dehumanization of the adversarial group of a past conflict. Which AIV will be perceived as most fair should depend on people's membership in victim or perpetrator groups, and their beliefs in the superiority of this group over other groups. This theory will be tested in ten empirical studies in multiple countries, utilizing a mix of research designs. Participants will include heterogeneous and representative groups of adults, some whom have experienced past international or inter-ethnic conflict.

This research tests hypotheses of theoretical and scholarly interest at the center of important large-scale social problems. Knowledge gained from this work will be of interest to scholars from a broad range of disciplines (e.g., foreign/ international relations, international law, political science, psychology, sociology) and will inform our understanding of and decisions about AIVs. Therefore, this research constitutes an important step in working towards minimizing international or inter-ethnic violence and maximizing reconciliation and peace. This project will also provide unique, interdisciplinary training and education for graduate researchers and undergraduate research assistants, including some from under-represented backgrounds. Research findings will be disseminated through journal publications and conference presentations, as well as through NGOs and other entities outside of academia.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the past 25 years, an international debate has been brewing about how to approach conflicts between national, ethnic or religious groups in order to achieve reconciliation and peace. Despite psychology’s longstanding interest in such intergroup violence, little attention has been paid to approaches to intergroup violence (AIVs) such as impunity, trials, or truth commissions. Thus, despite their widespread use, they have been poorly understood. To date, existing theories underlying the debate over different AIVs suffered from a lack of theorizing as to how/why predicted effects would emerge, and from a lack of rigorous empirical investigations of the predicted effects.

In this project, we developed a model explaining the consequences and underlying mechanisms of different AIVs among perpetrators and victims. We tested this model in 14 empirical studies in multiple countries, utilizing a mix of experimental, quasi-experimental, and correlational designs, and heterogeneous and representative adult samples (rather than college student samples). First and foremost, we examined situational (e.g., victim vs. perpetrator status) and dispositional factors (e.g., glorification of one’s country) in an effort to explain people’s reactions to intergroup violence followed by impunity or international criminal trials. In a nutshell, we found that people who strongly glorify their own country are more supportive of future violence against, and less willing to reconcile with, other groups when the country has suffered victimization from these groups rather than itself perpetrated violence against these groups. We replicated these effects with both Americans in context of American-Iranian tensions, and with Serbs in context of the Bosnian War between Serbs and Bosniaks. We further showed that demands for retributive and restorative justice, respectively, explained why victims who glorify their own country reacted this way and why those who do not glorify their own country did not react this way. Last but not least, we also demonstrated that international criminal tribunals such as the one in the former Yugoslavia make even strongly glorifying victims less supportive of future violence and more willing to reconcile with the other side of the past conflict.

This project has therefore generated evidence-based knowledge on the mechanisms and outcomes of approaches to intergroup violence (e.g. international criminal tribunals). From a disciplinary (i.e. psychological) perspective, it helped to illuminate the link between (different kinds of) justice and peace/reconciliation. For example, it advanced theory and empirical knowledge of retributive and restorative justice. Further, it integrated hitherto separate lines of research, on victims and perpetrators of intergroup violence, respectively. This project also has many ties to other disciplines, e.g. political science, conflict and security studies, sociology, and public health, among others. Thus, we also disseminated our findings in interdisciplinary journals read by audiences within and outside of psychology; altogether, the project has led to 3 publications of new theoretical perspectives; 5 publications of our empirical findings; several presentations at national and international conferences; several interviews with popular media outlets; and the acquisition of smaller grant funding from private foundations for “spin-off projects” that originated from this project. The project has also contributed to the training and professional development of 4 graduate students and about 30 undergraduate research assistants, who have been involved in the various studies we conducted and published. Moreover, this project contributed to the transformation of the long-standing divide between basic (process oriented) and applied (problem-oriented) research by testing hypotheses of theoretical and scholarly interest at the center of important large-scale social problems. Knowledge gained from this research informs our understanding of and decisions about AIVs. As such, this project constitutes an important (first) step in working towards minimizing intergroup violence and maximizing intergroup reconciliation and peace.
